metadata.case_name: Messrs. Eastern Overseas (Pondicherry) & Ors. v. Union of India & Ors.

facts.text: Two firms obtained patentes to carry on business in Pondicherry in September 1954 for the first time; no prior business in Pondicherry; proprietors residents of New Delhi and Bombay.
Orders for import placed before August 15, 1954; authorisations obtained from French authorities; foreign exchange acquired in open market.

Shipments delayed due to dock strike in England and Continent and lack of shipping space; most of 29 consignments shipped after November 1, 1954; only three shipped in October 1954; goods arrived after November 1, 1954.
Administration of Pondicherry taken over by Union of India from November 1, 1954 pursuant to Indo-French agreement.

S.R.O.s Nos. 3314 and 3315 issued on October 30, 1954, effective November 1, 1954; extended Sea Customs Act 1878, Imports and Exports Control Act 1947, etc., to Pondicherry; para 6 saving clause for things done or omitted before commencement.
Press communique November 1, 1954: imports regulated by Imports and Exports Control Act 1947; advised to apply for validation of pre-November 1 licences.
Petitioners applied for validation of authorisations; refused by Chief Controller of Imports and Exports, Pondicherry.
Goods arrived; clearance sought from Collector of Customs; denied; show cause notices issued for contravention of Imports and Exports Control Act 1947 and Sea Customs Act 1878.
Collector of Customs ordered confiscation or penalties (over Rs.64,000 and Rs.96,000); petitioners argued orders placed before Aug 15 1954 per pre-Nov 1 law.
Appeals to Central Board of Revenue dismissed; penalties reduced to over Rs.35,000 and Rs.60,000.
Revisions to Government of India rejected on January 23, 1957; penalties paid, goods cleared.
No court challenge until after Universal Imports decision; representations made, last in August 1961.
Supreme Court in Universal Imports Agency (1960) held para 6 SRO 3315 saves pre-Nov 1 contracts/authorisations; penalties refunded there.
Petitioners sought refund post-Universal; denied February 1961 and August 1961.
Press communique January 5, 1955: open market transactions after Nov 1 unauthorised; concessions for genuine pre-Aug 15 orders shipped pre-Nov 1.
Collector found no proof of pre-Aug 15 orders: firms started Sept 1954, no prior business/correspondence; no shipments pre-Nov 1 except three.
Board held imports without licence post-Nov 1; silent on pre-Aug 15 fact but reduced penalty.

legal_issues.text: Whether petitions under Art. 32 are maintainable to challenge quasi-judicial orders (confiscation/penalties) under intra vires statutes based solely on misconstruction of para 6 of SRO 3315.
Whether authorities lacked inherent jurisdiction due to saving clause protecting pre-Nov 1 transactions, allowing Art 32 challenge.
Whether firm orders/contracts placed before Nov 1, 1954, saved by para 6 SRO 3315 from Sea Customs Act/Imports Control Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Cases identical to Universal Imports Agency; firm orders before Aug 15/Nov 1 1954, authorisations, exchange arranged pre-Nov 1; para 6 saves transactions and consequences; entitled to refund of penalties.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Para 6 SRO 3315; Universal Imports Agency v. Chief Controller (1961) 1 SCR 305; Art 19(1)(f)(g), Art 32

petitioner_arguments.text: Orders without jurisdiction as Sea Customs Act inapplicable per saving clause; Ujjambai exception for lack of jurisdiction applies.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art 32; Ujjambai v. State of UP (1963) 1 SCR 778 (as interpreted)

respondent_arguments.text: Petitions not maintainable under Art 32 per Ujjambai; quasi-judicial orders under intra vires statutes (Sea Customs Act via SRO 3315); mere misconstruction not challengeable.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Ujjambai v. State of UP (1963) 1 SCR 778; Art 32

respondent_arguments.text: No proof of pre-Aug 15 orders: firms new in Sept 1954, no prior business/correspondence; shipments post-Nov 1 without validation/licence; mala fide to defeat Indian laws.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Imports and Exports Control Act 1947; Sea Customs Act 1878 s 167(8)

court_reasoning.text: Majority (Wanchoo J.): Ujjambai applies; authorities had jurisdiction; misconstruction of para 6 (part of extended Sea Customs Act) not challengeable under Art 32; Universal Imports not on jurisdiction lack; petitioners' pre-Aug 15 fact finding upheld; alternative para 6 claim implicitly rejected by Board via misconstruction, still not maintainable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order under intra vires law with jurisdiction cannot be challenged under Art 32 solely for misconstruction.

court_reasoning.text: Petitioners rested on pre-Aug 15 before Collector (fact finding against them); Board rejected licence implicitly via para 6 misconstruction but jurisdiction present.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No inherent jurisdiction lack; Universal Imports turned on misconstruction, not jurisdiction.

court_reasoning.text: Das Gupta J. (separate): Preliminary objection fails; if pre-Nov 1 contracts, no jurisdiction under Sea Customs (per Universal); authority cannot assume jurisdiction by wrong collateral fact; but evidence insufficient on merits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Jurisdiction absent if saving clause applies; writ maintainable for jurisdictional error.

holdings.text: Petitions under Art 32 not maintainable to challenge quasi-judicial orders under intra vires taxing statutes based solely on misconstruction of provisions.
No distinction between assessment and confiscation/penalty orders; Ujjambai governs.

precedents_cited.case_name: Smt. Ujjambai v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Quasi-judicial orders under intra vires statutes not challengeable under Art 32 for mere misconstruction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Messrs. Universal Imports Agency v. Chief Controller of Imports and Exports
precedents_cited.relevance: Para 6 saves pre-Nov 1 transactions; but not based on lack of jurisdiction; misconstruction case.

precedents_cited.case_name: State Trading Corporation of India v. State of Mysore
precedents_cited.relevance: Art 32 lies for jurisdictional error on collateral fact.
Inferior tribunal cannot assume jurisdiction by wrongly deciding collateral fact.

precedents_cited.case_name: Leo Roy Frey v. Superintendent District Jail, Amritsar
precedents_cited.relevance: Customs authority acts quasi-judicially under s 167(8) Sea Customs Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kailash Nath v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Pre-Ujjambai writs on misconstruction; lost validity post-Ujjambai.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petitions for enforcement of fundamental rights; maintainability threshold.

statutes_cited.name: Sea Customs Act, 1878
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for confiscation/penalties; extended to Pondicherry; quasi-judicial.

statutes_cited.name: Foreign Jurisdiction Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for SRO 3315 extending laws to Pondicherry.

statutes_cited.name: French Establishments (Application of Laws) Order, 1954 (SRO 3315)
statutes_cited.relevance: Saving clause for pre-commencement things done; central to misconstruction.

outcome.summary: Petitions dismissed on preliminary objection of maintainability under Art 32 per Ujjambai; no merit consideration by majority as writ incompetent for challenging jurisdictional quasi-judicial orders on misconstruction grounds.
outcome.costs: Dismissed with costs - one set of hearing costs.

key_quotes.text: "An order of assessment made by an authority under a taxing statute which is intra vires and in the undoubted exercise of its jurisdiction cannot be challenged on the sole ground that it is passed on a misconstruction of a provision of the Act or of a notification issued thereunder."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Das J. in Ujjambai, adopted by majority.

key_quotes.text: "No tribunal of inferior jurisdiction can by its own decision finally decide on the question of the existence or extent of such jurisdiction."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rex v Shoreditch, cited in dissent for jurisdictional error.

key_quotes.text: "The words 'things done' must be reasonably interpreted and if so interpreted they not only meant things done but also the legal consequence flowing therefrom."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Universal Imports on para 6 saving clause.
